docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the ban made sense because it would cut the health risks of secondhand smoke and reduce littering by smokers.

headline.seo: Bloomberg Weighs Smoking Ban in Parks
headline.main: Mayor Leans Toward a Smoking Ban at Parks and Beaches
headline.print_headline: Bloomberg Is Open to a Smoking Ban at Parks and Beaches

docs.snippet: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the ban made sense because it would cut the health risks of secondhand smoke and reduce littering by smokers.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the first time in more than a decade, New York's beekeepers are claiming their summer perches on the city's rooftops. Bowing to a citywide campaign, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene recently removed honeybees from the Health Code's register of ''venomous insects'' and other prohibited animals. Not surprisingly, the New York City Beekeepers Association saw a sizable bump in enrollment for its spring classes. Yet without support from City Hall, it's doubtful that we can return to anything like the pre-ban era, when hives could be found at city schools, on the roof of the American Museum of Natural History and even inside Radio City Music Hall.
docs.abstract: Hugh Raffles Op-Ed article cites benefits of urban beekeeping, contending honey made from New York City's beekeepers is likely to have much less chemical residue than commercial honey; lists ways local honey helps New Yorkers with allergies and benefits health of planet; praises Health and Mental Hygiene Dept for removing honeybees from venomous insects list but urges City Hall to support urban beekeeping through grants and other programs; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After years of effort to coax empathy from machines, robots and devices designed to soothe, support and keep us company are venturing out of the laboratory.
